awd_titl_txt: RUI: Phosphine-Directed Carbon-Hydrogen Borylation to Access Ambiphilic Phosphine Boronates
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the Chemical Catalysis program of the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Timothy Clark of the University of San Diego is developing metal-catalyzed reactions that convert a carbon-hydrogen ("C-H") bond to a carbon-boron bond. These reactions are "directed" by a phosphorus atom (called a "phosphine") on the target molecule.  This chemical reaction is unusual as C-H bonds are rather unreactive and will not undergo this change without the phosphine. The focus of this project is on using the phosphine to direct the metal catalyst to a particular C-H bond in the molecule, providing compounds that have a specific spatial relationships. By incorporating boronates into these phosphines, new reactions are developed that leverage the complementary reactivity of the phosphine and boronates. The Clark group is accessing a large variety of phosphine boronates and applying them to reactions in organic chemistry that can facilitate the synthesis of organic molecules, including those of relevance to medicinal or energy-related applications. Dr. Clark works primarily with undergraduate students. This project provide undergraduate students with research experiences, preparing them for careers in STEM fields.  This research also advances the national interest by providing innovation in chemical synthesis and pharmaceutical design and development.

Dr. Timothy Clark is developing phosphine-directed C-H borylation reactions and using the resulting ambiphilic phosphine boronates toward new organic and organometallic transformations. The C-H borylation reaction uses a unique cationic iridium system to catalyze the directed C-H functionalization. A detailed mechanistic study is underway to further understand the catalytic cycle and improve the system. The phosphine substrates utilized in this transformation are being expanded to include sp3-hybridized C-H bonds and to access chiral phosphine boronates. The resulting phosphine boronates are being examined as ambiphilic ligands in challenging catalytic transformations. Further functionalization of the C-B bond is also being explored to access highly-functionalized phosphines as ligands in catalysis. In addition to developing high-impact processes in the area of catalysis, a primary focus of this grant is on mentoring undergraduate students in metal-catalyzed reactions, improving the pipeline of future STEM scientists in this important area of chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to develop reactions that utilize a phosphorus functional group to direct the catalytic C-H borylation of arenes. Phosphorus-containing molecules have extensive applications in agrochemistry, applications in pharmaceuticals, and serve as ligands in metal-catalyzed reactions. In this final application, ligands bind to metals and dictate their reactivity toward other molecules. Developing new reactions that selectively incorporate boron into phosphorus-containing molecules opens the door to making new versions of these classes of compounds, which have applications in all three of these areas (agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and metal-catalyzed reactions).

The C-H borylation reaction replaces an unreactive carbon-hydrogen bond with a reactive and versatile carbon-boron bond. Our group initially developed phosphine-directed C-H borylation reaction. This was a more general method than previous reported by our group and relied on a cationic iridium catalyst, which had not been used in C-H borylation before, to afford the observed reactivity (published in Angewandte Chemie, International Edition). We also extended this work to alkanes by developing the phosphorus-directed benzylic C-H, C-O, and C-N borylation (published in the Journal of Organic Chemistry). Through a collaboration, we then extended our work in the C-H borylation of phosphorus-containing compounds to those of phosphonates (published in the Journal of the American Chemical Society). Phosphonates are not prone to oxidation and have more versatility in terms of the final phosphorus group. 

Since our early work in phosphorus-directed C-H borylation, several variations of the transformation have been reported by other researchers, which prompted us to write a review of phosphorus-directed C-H borylation in 2021 (published in Advanced Synthesis and Catalysis).

The results of this grant were presented externally, including 6 abstracts at national ACS meetings and 5 invited departmental seminars (both categories have lower output than normal due to COVID restrictions).

This grant funded the training of twelve undergraduate research students, contributing to the pipeline of the scientific workforce. Of these twelve students, six students are pursuing graduate work (four currently in programs and two applying), four students are in the industrial workforce, and two students are pursuing medical school (one currently attending medical school and one applying). 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Timothy B Clark
